sentences.full_text: Naake Chekelle Mashkokaałe hahche-tôklâacheka emmeke enkaktahônkat ômmesh.
sentences.translation_en: What Chekilli, the head-chief of the Upper and Lower Creeks said,
notes: Original transcription: Náki Tchikílli Maskoká'li há'htchi tukládshiga ímmigi ingaktahúnkat û'mmis.

sentences.full_text: “ Savannah” okle lahkahche emanooleeshpe chokpe-choobe-łâamen choke-kolapâaken pokôole-tochêenan chahkêep-awâykak-fôokon ênkahen, yatêhkot maam’kônkash enkahen yanash-hâlbon onchaohôolektawa( ch); aponke yâamooshen:
sentences.translation_en: in a talk held at Savannah, anno 1735, and which was handed over by the interpreter, written upon a Buffalo-skin, was, word for word, as follows:

sentences.full_text: Chaachaałe e̠e̠yakne“ Savannah” oklon lahkahche emanóoleeshpe chokpe-choobe łâamen choke kolapâaken pokoole-tochêenan chakpe waykakfôokon Chekelle Mashkokaałe hahche toklâacheka emmekot apoonektahônkat ômmesh;§
sentences.translation_en: [Speech, which, in the year 1735, was delivered at Savannah, in Georgia, by] Chekilli, Emperor of the Upper and Lower Creeks;

sentences.full_text: Anteche Káwete okle emmekapékche, Elayche meke, Osta Kasihtaałe emmeke, Tamecha hołle meke; Wale Palâhchoklaałe ehołle kapetaane, Puepayche meke; Tamhueche Yochetaałe eef-meke; Metekaaye Okoonaałe enhołle-meke, Towechayche meke; Woyahne Cheyaahaałe Ok-môlkaałe eshyâameka emmeke; Eshtemalaakuehche Oshochaałe emmeke; Hopełe Shaawoklaałe emmeke; Ewanaake meke; Tahmokme Yofantaałe ehołe kapetaane, tashtenakaałe pokoole-tocheenak ayâmkan eshayyak apoonek onkaktawa( ch)
sentences.translation_en: Antiche, highest Chief of the Town of the Cowetas, Eliche, King; Ousta, Head-chief of the Cussitaws, Tomechaw, War-king; Wali, War-captain of the Palachucolas, Poepiche, King; Tomehuichi, Dog-king of the Euchitaws; Mittakawye, Head War-chief of the Okonees, Tuwechiche, King; Whoyauni, Head War-chief of the Chehaws and of the Hokmulge Nation ; Stimelacoweche, King of the Osoches; Opithll, King of the Sawokolos, Ewenauki, King; Tahmokmi, War-captain of the Eufantees; and thirty other Warriors.

sentences.full_text: Nehtake êełen yaknot( haash) -kaałale łatâakon hawâklen Kashehtaałe( a) lok-łanêshyaktawa( ch) yakne echon mâahamek labankooshon eełektawa( ch), mâameshka yaknot wetehkak hoposhkon emanôolehen enheełatek showashkaachek kaałale łataakon eełektawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: At a certain time the Earth opened in the West, where its mouth is. The Earth opened and the Cussitaws came out of its mouth, and-settled nearby. But the Earth became angry and ate up their children; therefore, they moved further West. A part of them, however, turned back, and came again to the same place where they had been, and settled there. The greater number remained behind, because they thought it best to do so.

sentences.full_text: Mâameshka alahkot yalashkaachek eełektahônka noołaachek eełektawa( ch).
Mâameshka achook-apêkchakat yoobalaalon eełektawa( ch);“ maamekanton amakmôowa( ch)” âklete̠.
Mâamen ômme mâameshka yakne hopôshke emanoolektahônka emônkahen ebashnaachetek hantot haa( sh) łanaa( ke) łataakon ałaachektawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: Their children, nevertheless, were eaten by the Earth, so that, full of dissatisfaction, they journeyed toward the sunrise.

sentences.full_text: Mâahamek oke-choobe chêkte okofke sheleete talâaken oołaachek mon etaolek-kaachek feshahkek neełake łâamen noshcheechektawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: They came to a thick, muddy, slimy river—came there, camped there, rested there, and stayed overnight there.

sentences.full_text: Hayatlen ałaachek oke-choobe keteshcha(?)
sentences.translation_en: The next day they continued their journey and came, in one day, to a red, bloody river.

sentences.full_text: pechekch-ômmehchot talâakan oołaachek, mon eełek łaałoshk-emempeepak lahkahche tôklan eełektawa( ch); mâameshka ok-aashot hamhôopooshen eełeeke emmâameteehen(?).
sentences.translation_en: They lived by this river, and ate of its fishes for two years; but there were low springs there; and it did not please them to remain.

sentences.full_text: Ya oke-choobe pechekch-ômmeka eekape łataakon ałâachekan tonohkahch-onkahchon enhâklek hanton ônkahoosh âklek heecheekon ebashnaachek onałaachektawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: They went toward the end of this bloody river, and heard a noise as of thunder. They approached to see whence the noise came.

sentences.full_text: Enchawatke ochke keteshchon hechaktawa( ch) mâamen łane(= bèeke) -chayhe tonohkahchon, mâamen łane-chayhe epâakenon hopaanâhch-onkâhchon enhaklektawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: At first they perceived a red smoke, and then a mountain which thundered; and on the mountain was a sound as of singing.

sentences.full_text: Naakot ômmeka ataałeekon âklek(,) yaaton ontakashłektawa( ch); mâamekan eete choobâhchot âmbe łataakon alafank(?)
sentences.translation_en: They sent to see what this was; and it was a great fire which blazed upward, and made this singing noise.

sentences.full_text: -ômmekat hopaanehch-onkomehen hechaktawa( ch).
Ya łane-chayhe łane-chaye lapkon emmekon kaachek hocheefaktawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: This mountain they named the King of Mountains.

sentences.full_text: Yâameshka tonohkâhche emônkawa( ch), mâamen yaate immałashleecheekot ômmewa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: It thunders to this day; and men are very much afraid of it.

sentences.full_text: Yàalon yaate okle małayhke tocheenen atabakshektawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: They here met a people of three different Nations.

sentences.full_text: Łane-chayhe hayokahahche hechakfôkot wełe eshehshôomet eshyaoleechektawa( ch); mâamek mon ayekchoshka naanoomehchok shonâabaka mon ataałektawa( ch), mâamek naake achonkon ataałktawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: They had taken and saved some of the fire from the mountain ; and, at this place, they also obtained a knowledge of herbs and of many other things.

sentences.full_text: Haash-łanâhchon ontêhchot wełe hâtkot emêelakma naanoomeecheteektawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: From the East, a white fire came to them; which, however, they would not use.

sentences.full_text: Wahaalon ontêhchot eete holaytlot[ honotbot] eelaktawa( ch); maa’ka(?)
sentences.translation_en: From Wahalle came a fire which was blue ; neither did they use it. From the West came a fire which was black; nor would they use it.

sentences.full_text: naanoomeechetektawa( ch).
XXX Shanachke honeełon ontekat wełe keteshchokma laknôotomektawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: At last, came a fire from the North, which was red and yellow.

sentences.full_text: Yan eete eshyaoleechehônkat etompelektahômet mon yâameshka ełeechek ômmesh; mâamen mâaka hopâanashka eełekat ômmewa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: This they mingled with the fire they had taken from the mountain ; and this is the fire they use to-day ; and this, too, sometimes sings.

sentences.full_text: Łane chayhon pòok-aapot onhachâalek ommekat chonosh-hé̠e̠łalàatek hant onkahchot ommekan, naanoomeechokan chonosh-hé̠e̠ława( ch) enkashka yaate âytektawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: On the mountain was a pole which was very restless and made a noise, nor would anyone say how it could be quieted.

sentences.full_text: Mahamen(?)
emaapon yaatooche eeke aytoshehchon eshek eshayaatablek yaatooche eleehoochektawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: At length they took a motherless child, and struck it against the pole; and thus killed the child. They then took the pole, and carry it with them when they go to war. It was like a wooden tomahawk, such as they now use, and of the same wood.

sentences.full_text: Maamehaychek ma pòokaape eshek hołe ałâacheka eshyaoleechet ommewa( ch).
Atashe ommehchot ommektawa( ch), yâameshka eshyaoleechesh ma ommehchot ommektawa( ch) ahe malaalot ommewa( ch).

Yan ayekchot małayhke sheetaakek enhechkaktawa( ch) hopaanak naanoomeecheekoka onaal( h) ehen ataałaktawa( ch); enchewatke pashôohen; shatoklaka, hoyaneechon, akshe keteshche, estocheenakat, shawachkon, eshsheetaakakekat, akchomoochôohen.
sentences.translation_en: Here they also found four herbs or roots, which sang and disclosed their virtues : first, Pasaw, the rattlesnake root; second, Micoweanochaw, red-root ; third, Sowatchko, which grows like wild fennel; and fourth, Eschalapootche, little tobacco. These herbs, especially the first and third, they use as the best medicine to purify themselves at their Busk. At this Busk, which is held yearly, they fast, and make offerings of the first fruits. Since they learned the virtues of these herbs, their women, at certain times, have a separate fire, and remain apart from the men five, six and seven days, for the sake of purification. If they neglect this the power of the herbs would depart; and the women would not be healthy.

sentences.full_text: Ya naake yâameka passion showaachkon eshtoklaka ennehtak-honlan eełekfôoke eshelafeshtaylêchôot omewa( ch).
Nehtake mâame enchânken eełekfôoket nâakot enchewâtke hâayak ommeka mon waylêhchôot omewa( ch).

Ya nâake yâameka enhechâykaktahônka ałeeyaka hotaykoshka etamoołaachewa( ch), mâamekfôoke laamoołon etaoletkaachek, honakne awelaachetek nehtake chahkeepashka eepaakeshka kolapaakeshka oołahen( a) lokontêh’t omewa( ch); mâameteka ya ayekche enhechkâhche eshyaolêecheka enhampaachewa( tesh); mâamehen hotaykak châahchoonot yaoleechetekosh.

Mâameka fôokon hântot naknooshôot ommek“ nâakoshka yâhmête̠sh” ênkan yaoleechoh-shonaâbahosh etekaachek eshyaoleechek; mâamôot omête̠sh” etekaachek okle sheetaake,“ pookaape sheetaaken chepehlêhchek lokfon eshketeshchaachôote̠sh; laknôot ommekma nohaachokan keteshchâhchôot ommete̠” etekaachektawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: About that time a dispute arose, as to which was the oldest, and which should rule; and they agreed, as they were four Nations, they would set up four poles, and make them red with clay, which is yellow at first, but becomes red by burning. They would then go to war; and whichever Nation should first cover its pole, from top to bottom, with the scalps of their enemies, should be the oldest.

sentences.full_text: “ Mahâyhmek hołlon ałaachôote̠sh; mâamen okle naanoomekat behkon pookaape chepehleechekaka ehołle yoosh-halbon ellompelaalek loboleechen ommekaaye mot naknoosh-apêkchakat ommelâakash” etekaachektawa( ch).
Lâpkot mamehcheeke aklek ommekma, Kashehtaałok XXX
sentences.translation_en: They all tired, but the Cussitaws covered their pole first, and so thickly that it was hidden from sight. Therefore, they were looked upon, by the whole Nation, as the oldest. The Chickasaws covered their pole next; then the Atilamas; but the Obikaws did not cover their pole higher than the knee.

sentences.full_text: Maamek fooke fooshe choobahchot, hoolatlot, haache baachkihchot, hachetolame esheenpatkot, neehtak laapkon eelak, yaaton eleeshchik emanoleehchot ommektawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: At that time there was a bird of large size, blue in color, with a long tail, and swifter than an eagle, which came every day and killed and ate their people. They made an image in the shape of a woman, and placed it in the way of this bird. The bird carried it off, and kept it a long time, and then brought it back. They left it alone, hoping it would bring something forth. After a long time a red rat came forth from it, and they believe the bird was the father of the rat. They took council with the rat how to destroy its father. Now the bird had a bow and arrows; and the rat gnawed the bowstring, so that the bird could not defend itself, and the people killed it. They called this bird the King of Birds. They think the eagle is also a great King; and they carry its feathers when they go to War or make Peace: the red mean War; the white, Peace. If an enemy approaches with white feathers and a white mouth, and cries like an eagle, they dare not kill him.

sentences.full_text: Tayk-aabon omek fooshe elaahche etonaayakan enhachaleechektawa( ch).
Fooshe ełak eshek shałeyaahoomet acheeban eshealaakak yehonchektawa( ch).
Naakoshka hechleecheshka ełewach aakłek nanoomecheteehen ałeeyaktawa( ch); acheebahen cheshe keteshchot alokłaneeyahen, ma fooshot ełkoowach aaklektawa( ch).
Ma cheshe etemaposhneechek eełke nanoomechookat emellechohoosh aakłek esheaolechektawa( ch); ma fooshe efche-kotokbon łaake ayaamkon ełecheχtchot ommektawa( ch).
Cheeshot eefche-kotokbe aakshon kaleefkak enkoshlehen naanoomek elemaashatay shonaaban oomehen elehoochektawa( ch).
Hachetolam akaa meke choobot ômmesh aakłot ommewach, maamek ehaache hołoshka ałaachewa( ch); maamik etehełkeekoshka aakłek yaa-olecheka mon esheaolechehchot ommewa( ch).
Keteeshchakat hołoohen haat kakat hełkeekot ommewa( ch).
Enhołooshka alokontelaka eełewa( ch) maamen oomek-fooke foosh-eheeshki haatkon ełeechek echon ħatleechik hachetolaami onkahchot onkak alokonten ommekaaye, eleehchehlatehchot ommewa( ch).
Yaa e-obalon ełaahonka honchek ałaachek heene haatkot talaakan ołaachektawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: After this they left that place, and came to a white foot-path. The grass and everything around were white; and they plainly perceived that people had been there. They crossed the path, and slept near there. Afterward they turned back to see what sort of path that was, and who the people were who had been there, in the belief that it might be better for them to follow that path. They went along it to a creek called Coloose-hutche, that is Coloose-creek, because it was rocky there and smoked.

sentences.full_text: Pahoshka nak-laapkot haatkoktawa( ch); maamete yaatot ya-oleeche-heełot ommehen heechaχtawa( ch).
Heene tafaamashkachek emaweeloshehen noshcheechektawa( ch).
Ma haihemeehche e-oobale yalashkaachek, hene naanomot ommeesh-akaa ya-olechokanton heełoshka oomekosh aaklektawa( ch).
Mon aleetak ałaachek haahche Kolooshe kaachekon olaachektawa( ch); Kolooshe kaacheka taale ayookahchot ommek pafaakchehchot ommete mon hocheefak onkaktawa( ch).
Łaneshyaachek haashe-łaana łafaakon ałaachek oklon Kooshe ehkeekot eełehen olaachektawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: They crossed it, going toward the sunrise, and came to a people and a town named Coosaw. Here they remained four years. The Coosaws complained that they were preyed upon by a wild beast, which they called man-eater or lion, which lived in a rock.

sentences.full_text: Yaan êełen lahkaahche sheetake oołaktwa( ch).
Kooshałot onkakat" yaat-empot aayak yaaton pomanoleehchot ommehchaamash" eenkaktawa( ch)," taale okbon afokshak omhahmesh" eenkahen.
Kashehtaałot onkakat:\" eleecheke akłeekalakash\" kaachektawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: The Cussitaws said they would try to kill the beast. They digged a pit and stretched over it a net made of hickory-bark. They then laid a number of branches, crosswise, so that the lion could not follow them, and, going to the place where he lay, they threw a rattle into his den. The lion rushed forth in great anger, and pursued them through the branches. Then they thought it better that one should die rather than all; so they took a motherless child, and threw it before the lion as he came near the pit. The lion rushed at it and fell in the pit, over which they threw the net, and killed him with blazing pine-wood. His bones, however, they keep to this day; on one side, the yare red; on the other, blue.

sentences.full_text: Yaknon ka-élek hayohkon oomek oochake haalbon taałak abootoleechik ahoposhkon onshalek yaatepe achakontete shonaaban ommek.
Mamee hayhchek onałaachek shaa-okon emooklon emompełpahen.

Yaat-epe weteehkah-heełot alokłeneekak ahoposhkee chohłoolek ashoowahen; maamek-fôokon yaate łaamoshek enlekaanton aheełowa( ch), laapk-apekchaakat mameteewa( ch), aakłek, yaakne kaa-eke awelaachen ek-emeloochon behkon empełban, onłeneekak yaakne-kay-ekon onałaalehen, oochak-haalbe taałahche ełeechehonkat onalobeechek choye ayokaahahchon eshbataashbik eleechektawa( ch).
Efoon-akaa yaameshka ełeeche emonkawa( ch); apaloakat keteshchoohen, apaalowot hoolatlot ommewa( ch).
Yaat-epe nehtaake kolapaakek fôokon eelak yaate eleeshchehchot ommektawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: The lion used to come every seventh day to kill the people: therefore, they remained there seven days after they had killed him. In remembrance of him, when they prepare for War, they fast six days and start on the seventh. If they take his bones with them, they have good fortune.

sentences.full_text: Maaete eleechek fooe malaalon êełen nehtake kolapaake oołaktawa( ch).
Ma eshałéhkon hołoshka ałaachahek emetonaabaka empateehen nehtake eepake oołan eshkolapaakekan ałacheehtchot ommewa( ch); efoonon eshiaolechek ommeka naake enhechkaheełot ommewa( ch).
Mahmaahonka lahkaahche sheetake oołan Koshałe honchek ałaacheka oke-choobe Noofape kaachekon ołaachektawa( ch); yamekaayi Kalooshe haahchon kahocheehchot ômmesh.
sentences.translation_en: After four years they left the Coosaws, and came to a river which they called Nowphawpe, now Callasi-hutche. There they tarried two years; and, as they had no corn, they lived on roots and fishes, and made bows, pointing the arrows with beaver teeth and flint-stones, and for knives they used split canes.

sentences.full_text: Mon êełen lahkaahche tokła oołaktawa( ch); maamen ashposhka aitechetee nakoshoshka eenka-elek eempak, łałoshka eempak, eefche-kotokboshka omek, eenłake poshaafe enootoshka chonołoshka abaanashlek emfashkeehche oomek, eshkalaafkoka ołaanon tokaylek ommektawa( ch).
Yaale eełehonka honhchek ałaacheka Waatole-onke haahchon ołaachektawa( ch), onka kaacheka mon waatolot oheełahchot ommete onkaktawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: They left this place, and came to a creek called Wattoola-hawka-hutche, Whooping-creek, so called from the whooping of cranes, a great many being there; they slept there one night. They next came to a river in which there was a waterfall; this they named the Owatunka river. The next day they reached another river, which they called the Aphoosa pheeskaw.

sentences.full_text: Mon neełake łaamen noshcheechektawa( ch).
Ma hayhemeehche ałaachika oke-choobe onałaalehchon ołaachek O-e-tomkon hocheefaktawa( ch).
Ełeen nehtake oke-choobe Afoshafeeshka kaachekon oshłaachektawa( ch).
Ełeen nehtake łanesyaachek, ałaachekat łane-chayhon ołaachekan, yaatot êełen ołaachek heene haatke ommeehche ya-olehchekat ommewa( ch) aaklektawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: The following day they crossed it, and came to a high mountain, where were people who, they believed, were the same who made the white path. They, therefore, made white arrows and shot them, to see if they were good people. But the people took their white arrows, painted them red, and shot them back. When they showed these to their chief, he said that it was not a good sign; if the arrows returned had been white, they could have gone there and brought food for their children, but as they were red they must not go. Nevertheless, some of them went to see what sort of people they were; and found their houses deserted, [sic] They also saw a trail which led into the river; and, as they could not see the trail on the opposite bank, they believed that the people had gone into the river, and would not again come forth.

sentences.full_text: Maamete łaake haatkon omek eshtchanaaplektawa( ch), yaate heełot ommeka ataałekon aaklek.
Maamekma ma yaate łaake haatke eshtchanaapleka keteshchaachek alokyalaleenchektawa( ch).

Maamen meekon hechahochekan," heełatek ômmesh," eenkaktawa( ch)," łaake alokyalaakakat haatkot ommahonka, onałaachek empekoska hoposke enhechlechachkaktahonkma; keteshchote onatełyahchaachkesh" kaachektawa( ch).

Maame hantaameshka yaate naanomot ommeka hecheekon aaklek onałaache yaamektawa( ch); maamekan chekasheepahen cheeke taankoohen heechaktawa( ch); maamekan ałaacheka heechkak ommekat oke-choobon kotaneshyachohen heechaktawa( ch); maamekat oshłaneshyaachekan hechateete oke-choobon kotaneshyaachek ommek, alokłaneshyaachetekosh aaklektawa( ch).
Mon łane-chayhot Moterell ehkekot chokoolek ommekat tamamaapk onkaahchot onkaht ommewa( ch); mon ma yaate eełek ommetokash ahkoolehchot ommewa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: At that place is a mountain, called Moterell, which makes a noise like beating on a drum; and they think this people live there. They hear this noise on all sides when they go to War.

sentences.full_text: Hołoshka ałaacheka hantontoshka enhakłeehchot ommewa( ch).

Ma oke-choobon apataleechek ałaachek oke onałaleehchon oshłaachekan taale hootehchot eełehen eefche-kotokbot onshalkaachen heechak," heene haatke ommehche yaa-olehchekat yaa-olechek ohmeshesh" aaklektawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: They went along the river till they came to a waterfall, where they saw great rocks, and on the rocks were bows lying; and they believed the people who made the white path had been there.

sentences.full_text: Haanton ałaachek yaa-olecheka toklak behkon yaa-okan ałaachehchot ommektawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: They always have, on their journeys, two scouts who go before the main body. These scouts ascended a high mountain and saw a town. They shot white arrows into the town; but the people of the town shot back red arrows. Then the Cussitaws became angry, and determined to attack the town, and each one have a house when it was captured. They threw stones into the river until they could cross it, and took the town (the people had flattened heads), and killed all but two persons. In pursuing these they found a white dog, which they slew. They followed the two who escaped, until they came again to the white path, and saw the smoke of a town, and thought that this must be the people they had so long been seeking. This is the place where now the tribe of Palachucolas live, from whom Tomochichi is descended.

sentences.full_text: Yaa behke yaa-okakat łane-chayhon onłanesheakan okłoohen heechaktawa( ch).
Łaake haatkon eshtchanaaplekan łaake keteshchon alokeshchanaaplektawa( ch).
Maamen Kashehtaałe wetekwookak eteebek okłon emeeshohen, ommek fooke tchekon shetonabekalaakash aaklektawa( ch).
Taalon oke-choobe kaabełbak łanook shonaaban omek okle emeeshekan( yaate e-ooshe pachakpaafot ommektawa( ch)) laapkon ohsheechehen; tokloshek alaahkektawa( ch).
Ashoowak eshałaachekan efe haatkot aayan ataabakshek eleechektawa( ch).
Tokla palaakakan ashoowak shałachek monkak łok heene haatke talaakakan eshołaachekan okloohen eetot pafaahshen heechak, mot yaate hopoyekahchaamat ommewa( ch), aaklektawa( ch).
Yaan Palahchoklaałe eełek ommehen Tamochaa-eche mon abeteleehchot hachaalek ômmesh.

Kashehtaałe pecheekche pehaalekon emalostahchot emonkak ommekma Palahcholaałot hełkeeke eshałayhkon ashon ewaylek:" pochonoshbe haathokot ômmesh, maamen cheeknak hatkalookatesh, maamek aatashe pechekch-okole-ka talaalek echeekne eshataałkalaka hatleechetesh," kaachektawa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: The Cussitaws continued bloody-minded; but the Palachucolas gave them black drink as a sign of friendship, and said to them: “Our hearts are white, and yours must be white, and you must lay down the bloody tomahawk, and show your bodies as proof that they shall be white.” Nevertheless, they were for the tomahawk; but the Palachucholas got it by persuasion, and buried it under their beds. The Palachucholas likewise gave them white feathers, and asked to have a chief in common. Since then they have always lived together.

sentences.full_text: Maamek hantaameshka atashonton emaaloshtot ommekma, Palahchoklaałot eshhonchechetek emeeshek emaaye ee-aknon hoopek; fosh-haatke heshk-akaa emeekak" pommeke łaamoshetesh" kaachektawa( ch).
Ma hayhmektahonka onaabaka etompehkak eełekchot ommewa( ch).

Aalahkot oke-choobe apaaloan eełehen, aalahkot apaaloan ełeχt ommewa( ch): apaloaahche eełekan Kashehtaałon kaachek; apaloaahche eełekan Kawetaałon kahocheehchot ommekma, okle łaamoshehchot ommewa( ch), maamek Haahchapaloaałe Haahchataałe yaameka okle esheehotoshot ommewa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: Some settled on one side of the river, some on the other. Those on one side are called Cussetaws, those on the other Cowetas; yet they are one people, and the principal towns of the Upper and Lower Creeks. Nevertheless, as the Cussetaws first saw the red smoke and the red fire, and make bloody towns, they cannot yet leave their red hearts, which are, however, white on one side and red on the other.

sentences.full_text: Maame hantaameshka Kashehtaało-kaanot ochke keteeshch-aka heechak eete keteeshchak-aaka he-echaktaahchot ommek okłe pechekchoshka ommektaahchote chonoshbe keteeshch-aka honchetek ômmeshka, apaaloak hatkoohen apaaloakat keteeshchot ommewa( ch).
Maamesh kayaameka heene hatka-kaantot eshenheełahchot ommeka ataałak-heełot ommewa( ch).
sentences.translation_en: They now know that the white path was the best for them: for, although Tomochichi was a stranger, they see he has done them good; because he went to see the great King with Esquire Oglethorpe, and heard his talk, and had related it to them, and they had listened to it, and believed it.

sentences.full_text: Tamechay-eche yaate atałkatehchot ommikma, naaki imaashahchot ommen ataałowa( ch); Okelłop achakałeeak meeke choobe ołheechak aponke enhak-lek, oołelak anaahen eenhaklek akaashamete.
